div1.p: Cooke attempts to identify people in the group photograph that Hench believes was taken at Camp Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from Robert P. Cooke to Philip Showalter Hench, December 16, 1944
div1.opener:
ROCKBRIDGE COUNTY HEALTH DEPARTMENT
LEXINGTON, VIRGINIA
Dec 16, 1944
IN COOPERATION WITH THE
STATE DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH
Lt. Colonel Philip S. Hen.
Hon Springs Arkansas
Dear Colonel Hench:
div1.p:
Your letter of the 1st was certainly enjoyed
and the letter from Gen Truby with the photograph
and press article was most interesting.

As to the Yellow Fever is taken hospital, I don't think
I was ever there, since I remained in quarantine
at Camp Lazear until returned to duty. Any
way, the cat is not [?]. As to the group pho-
tograph, nothing recalls it to my memory but I
believe Gen Trubys identification of the individ-
uals is substantially correct. It is cer-
tainly I under the tree. But I cant
ROCKBRIDGE COUNTY HEALTH DEPARTMENT
LEXINGTON, VIRGINIA
IN COOPERATION WITH THE
STATE DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH
imagine Maj. Reed in such a costume. and,
somehow, this looks like a younger man
but like him too. The group was probably taken after
quarantine was lifted - hence the children.
and it was I believe rather cool at that time
on account of a “norther” probably 45°
The man in the cap is confusing also. as I
don't recall any such - certainly most in-
appropriate headgear for Cuba- No 8 does not
look like sort of whom I saw at the Indianapolis
meeting in 1933?3 and 4 must be Jernegan
and Kissinger the ambulance is true
to life. Don't know contents of no 8's pack.
It looks like a bear key.

I am enclosing an enveloped photo of Walter
Reed as a student at Univ. of Va.
ROCKBRIDGE COUNTY HEALTH DEPARTMENT
LEXINGTON, VIRGINIA
IN COOPERATION WITH THE
STATE DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH
appearing in a group which was given me by Dr
Lawrence Royster' now living in Charlottesville.
Former head of the Dept. of Pediatrics.

I thought it might interest you to see
it. I am sorry I can't be more definite
about the photographs but one's memory
is undependable. I would indeed be
glad to have a few more copies of your
Hygeia article. With all good wishes
of the Season
